title: Chinese Government donates teaching materials to the Sisters of the Sacred Heart School
description: On February 26, 2016, the Chinese Government's China Commercial Development Office in Haiti donated teaching materials to the Sisters of the Sacred Heart School (French: Sœurs du Sacré Cœur). The donated teaching materials included microscopes, projectors, balances, and wall charts. The Sisters of the Sacred Heart School, located in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, was founded in 1905 to provide educational opportunities to girls from kindergarten to high school. It has nearly 1,500 students. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.
combined_text:

# Description
On February 26, 2016, the Chinese Government's China Commercial Development Office in Haiti donated teaching materials to the Sisters of the Sacred Heart School (French: Sœurs du Sacré Cœur). The donated teaching materials included microscopes, projectors, balances, and wall charts. The Sisters of the Sacred Heart School, located in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, was founded in 1905 to provide educational opportunities to girls from kindergarten to high school. It has nearly 1,500 students. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.
justification: Project focuses on educational support without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of teaching materials to school, education sector focus

title: Chinese Government donates sporting goods and equipment worth $30,000 USD to Haiti's Ministry of Youth, Sports, and Civic Action
description: On November 10, 2016, the Chinese Government's China Commercial Development Office in Haiti donated sporting goods and equipment worth approximately $30,000 USD to Haiti's Ministry of Youth, Sports, and Civic Action (MJSAC). The donated goods and equipment included basketballs, footballs (soccer balls), volleyballs, sports apparel and footwear, nets, and trophies.

# Description
On November 10, 2016, the Chinese Government's China Commercial Development Office in Haiti donated sporting goods and equipment worth approximately $30,000 USD to Haiti's Ministry of Youth, Sports, and Civic Action (MJSAC). The donated goods and equipment included basketballs, footballs (soccer balls), volleyballs, sports apparel and footwear, nets, and trophies.

title: Hanban provides a grant for the Confucius Center and Chinese language instruction at Quisqueya University (Linked to Project ID#71534)
description: On January 22, 2016, Hanban and Quisqueya University signed a cooperation agreement to set up Chinese language classes at Quisqueya University. Previously, on October 28, 2015, the Chinese Government's China Commercial Development Office in Haiti and Quisqueya University discussed intentions to send Chinese teachers to Haiti to offer the courses, with the Chinese covering the teacher’s salaries and round-trip travel expenses. On September 26, 2016, Quisqueya University held the opening ceremony of its Chinese language center, known as the Confucius Center of Quisqueya University (French: Centre Confucius de l’Université Quisqueya), which had the support of Hanban. Chinese courses were set to begin that same month, with one full-time Chinese teacher available. The language courses are being offered as a precursor to the potential development of a Confucius Institute at the university. In 2019, Hanban and Quisqueya University signed an agreement to establish a Confucius Classroom at Quisqueya University, as captured by linked project ID#71534.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title

# Description
On January 22, 2016, Hanban and Quisqueya University signed a cooperation agreement to set up Chinese language classes at Quisqueya University. Previously, on October 28, 2015, the Chinese Government's China Commercial Development Office in Haiti and Quisqueya University discussed intentions to send Chinese teachers to Haiti to offer the courses, with the Chinese covering the teacher’s salaries and round-trip travel expenses. On September 26, 2016, Quisqueya University held the opening ceremony of its Chinese language center, known as the Confucius Center of Quisqueya University (French: Centre Confucius de l’Université Quisqueya), which had the support of Hanban. Chinese courses were set to begin that same month, with one full-time Chinese teacher available. The language courses are being offered as a precursor to the potential development of a Confucius Institute at the university. In 2019, Hanban and Quisqueya University signed an agreement to establish a Confucius Classroom at Quisqueya University, as captured by linked project ID#71534.
justification: Project focuses on language education and cultural exchange without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Chinese language classes, Confucius Center, educational focus

title: Chinese Government provides scholarships to six Haitian students in 2016
description: In 2016, the Chinese Government awarded scholarships for study in China to six Haitian students. The scholarships allowed the students to study in China for three to six years. The China Commercial Development Office in Haiti held a farewell reception before the students were sent off on August 30, 2016.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Government provides scholarships to six Haitian students in 2016

# Description
In 2016, the Chinese Government awarded scholarships for study in China to six Haitian students. The scholarships allowed the students to study in China for three to six years. The China Commercial Development Office in Haiti held a farewell reception before the students were sent off on August 30, 2016.
justification: Project is focused on education and human development without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Scholarships for Haitian students, education-focused initiative

title: [China Co-Financing Fund] IDB administers 6 million USD loan from CHC to Ficohsa for SMEs
description: On 16 December 2016, the Inter-American Investment Corporation (IIC, now IDB Invest) signed a loan package with the Banco Financiera Comercial Hondureña (Ficohsa), through which IDB Invest would provide a 12 million USD subordinated loan with a 10 year term, to be paid in one installment at the end of the term, with a variable interest rate of LIBOR + 7% for the first and last five years. In the same contract, the OPEC Fund for International Development (OFID) provided a 12 million USD subordinated loan to the project as well.  For the purposes of this project, the average 6-month LIBOR in December 2016 (the date of signing of the agreement) was 1.306%, so the interest rate has been coded as 8.306%.  The China Co-Financing Fund for Latin America and the Caribbean (CHC), according to the project's page on the IDB Invest website and the OPEC Fund website, would provide an additional subordinated loan up to 6 million USD. Banco Fichosa's website also notes the total loan amount agreed upon in December 2016 was 30 million USD (12 million + 12 million + 6 million). However, internal financial documents from Banco Fichosa indicate that only 24 million USD, 12 million from both IDB Invest (IIC) and OFID, were provided as subordinated loans. Although it seems the 6 million USD from the CHC were included in the agreement, it is unclear whether Banco Ficohsa made use of this additional 6 million USD of financing.  The funding was intended to help Ficohsa increase access to finance for small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in Honduras, including women-led SMEs. It is hoped that the project will contribute to an estimated 15% growth in Ficohsa's portfolio of SME clients, as well as increase the share of women-led SMEs as part of the total portfolio from 32% today to more than 37% by December 2019.  The China Co-Financing Fund was established on 14 January 2013 with a contribution of 2 billion USD by the People's Bank of China, and it is administered by the IDB. For more information, see umbrella project ID #86526.
combined_text:
# Sector
BANKING AND FINANCIAL SERVICES

# Title
[China Co-Financing Fund] IDB administers 6 million USD loan from CHC to Ficohsa for SMEs

# Description
On 16 December 2016, the Inter-American Investment Corporation (IIC, now IDB Invest) signed a loan package with the Banco Financiera Comercial Hondureña (Ficohsa), through which IDB Invest would provide a 12 million USD subordinated loan with a 10 year term, to be paid in one installment at the end of the term, with a variable interest rate of LIBOR + 7% for the first and last five years. In the same contract, the OPEC Fund for International Development (OFID) provided a 12 million USD subordinated loan to the project as well.  For the purposes of this project, the average 6-month LIBOR in December 2016 (the date of signing of the agreement) was 1.306%, so the interest rate has been coded as 8.306%.  The China Co-Financing Fund for Latin America and the Caribbean (CHC), according to the project's page on the IDB Invest website and the OPEC Fund website, would provide an additional subordinated loan up to 6 million USD. Banco Fichosa's website also notes the total loan amount agreed upon in December 2016 was 30 million USD (12 million + 12 million + 6 million). However, internal financial documents from Banco Fichosa indicate that only 24 million USD, 12 million from both IDB Invest (IIC) and OFID, were provided as subordinated loans. Although it seems the 6 million USD from the CHC were included in the agreement, it is unclear whether Banco Ficohsa made use of this additional 6 million USD of financing.  The funding was intended to help Ficohsa increase access to finance for small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in Honduras, including women-led SMEs. It is hoped that the project will contribute to an estimated 15% growth in Ficohsa's portfolio of SME clients, as well as increase the share of women-led SMEs as part of the total portfolio from 32% today to more than 37% by December 2019.  The China Co-Financing Fund was established on 14 January 2013 with a contribution of 2 billion USD by the People's Bank of China, and it is administered by the IDB. For more information, see umbrella project ID #86526.
justification: Project involves financial services for SME development without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Loan package for SME financing, focus on business development and women-led enterprises

title: ICBC provides $80 million loan to IL&FS for infrastructure projects and creation of subsidiary company in transportation sector
description: On September 13, 2016, the Industrial & Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) and Infrastructure Leasing & Financial Services Group (IL&FS) signed an $80 million loan agreement for infrastructure projects and the creation of a subsidiary company -- known as IL&FS Transportation Networks Limited (ITNL) -- in the transportation sector. The loan's borrowing terms are unknown.  IL&FS is an Indian infrastructure financing company. It faced a severe liquidity crisis in 2018. Between July 2018 and September 2018, two of the subsidiaries of IL&FS Group reported having trouble in paying back loans and inter-corporate deposits to banks/lenders. In July 2018, the road arm of IL&FS was facing difficulty in making repayments due on its bonds. Further, in early September 2018, one of the subsidiaries of IL&FS Group was unable to repay a short-term loan of Rs. 1,000 crore taken from Small Industries Development Bank of India (SIDBI). Also, certain group companies defaulted in repayments of various short and long-term deposits, inter-corporate deposits, and commercial papers. IL&FS failed continuously to service its debt and the imminent possibility of a contagion effect in the financial market led the Central Government of India to move an application under Sections 241 and 242 of the Companies Act, 2013 before the NCLT, Mumbai Bench. It sought the immediate suspension of the Board of Directors of IL&FS and the appointment of specified new directors, on the ground of massive mismanagement of public funds by the erstwhile Board. It was also alleged that the affairs of the company were being conducted in a manner prejudicial to the public interest.
staff_comments: 1. Infrastructure Leasing & Financial Services Limited (IL&FS) is a systemically important Core Investment Company with the Reserve Bank of India and is engaged in the business of giving loans and advances to its group companies (and holding an investment in such companies). IL&FS has a large number of group companies across various sectors such as Energy, Transportation, Financial Services etc. IL&FS was initially promoted by the Central Bank of India, HDFC Limited and the Unit Trust of India. 2. India’s Life Insurance Corp Ltd is the biggest IL&FS shareholder with a more than 25 percent stake. IL&FS’s other large investors are ORIX Corp of Japan with a 23.54 percent stake, and the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority with 12.56 percent. India’s biggest lender by assets, State Bank of India, also owns a 6.42 percent stake in IL&FS.3. Phone numbers and email addresses for contacts are listed on page 3 of IL&FS source.
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
ICBC provides $80 million loan to IL&FS for infrastructure projects and creation of subsidiary company in transportation sector

# Description
On September 13, 2016, the Industrial & Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) and Infrastructure Leasing & Financial Services Group (IL&FS) signed an $80 million loan agreement for infrastructure projects and the creation of a subsidiary company -- known as IL&FS Transportation Networks Limited (ITNL) -- in the transportation sector. The loan's borrowing terms are unknown.  IL&FS is an Indian infrastructure financing company. It faced a severe liquidity crisis in 2018. Between July 2018 and September 2018, two of the subsidiaries of IL&FS Group reported having trouble in paying back loans and inter-corporate deposits to banks/lenders. In July 2018, the road arm of IL&FS was facing difficulty in making repayments due on its bonds. Further, in early September 2018, one of the subsidiaries of IL&FS Group was unable to repay a short-term loan of Rs. 1,000 crore taken from Small Industries Development Bank of India (SIDBI). Also, certain group companies defaulted in repayments of various short and long-term deposits, inter-corporate deposits, and commercial papers. IL&FS failed continuously to service its debt and the imminent possibility of a contagion effect in the financial market led the Central Government of India to move an application under Sections 241 and 242 of the Companies Act, 2013 before the NCLT, Mumbai Bench. It sought the immediate suspension of the Board of Directors of IL&FS and the appointment of specified new directors, on the ground of massive mismanagement of public funds by the erstwhile Board. It was also alleged that the affairs of the company were being conducted in a manner prejudicial to the public interest.
justification: Project focuses on general transportation infrastructure without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Loan for infrastructure projects and creation of transportation subsidiary, no specific environmental or energy-related details provided

title: Shanghai Library provides 700 books to Cheena Bhavana
description: On November 3, 2016, Cheena Bhavana, the Institute of Chinese Language and Culture at Visva-Bharat University, signed a three-year memorandum of agreement (MOA) with Shanghai Library. In this MOA, Shanghai Library committed to providing 500 copies of books in the first year, and then another 100 per year after that (a total of 700 books, given the agreement's three-year length). The agreement was intended to shore up collection of Cheena Bhavana's library and enhance library cooperation. The monetary value of this agreement is unknown.
staff_comments: Details about the implementation of this MOA are unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
Shanghai Library provides 700 books to Cheena Bhavana

# Description
On November 3, 2016, Cheena Bhavana, the Institute of Chinese Language and Culture at Visva-Bharat University, signed a three-year memorandum of agreement (MOA) with Shanghai Library. In this MOA, Shanghai Library committed to providing 500 copies of books in the first year, and then another 100 per year after that (a total of 700 books, given the agreement's three-year length). The agreement was intended to shore up collection of Cheena Bhavana's library and enhance library cooperation. The monetary value of this agreement is unknown.
justification: Project involves cultural exchange and library development without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Provision of books, library cooperation, cultural exchange focus

title: ICBC participates in $980 million syndicated loan for Reliance Industries for debt refinancing purposes
description: In March 2016, Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) participated in a $980 million syndicated loan facility agreement with Reliance Industries. The borrowing terms of the loan are unknown. The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower to refinance an existing facility (loan) that it contracted in August 2010. The participating banks in the March 2016 syndicated loan included ANZ, Bank of America, Bank of Nova Scotia Asia, Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ, Barclays Bank, Citibank, Credit Agricole CIB, DBS, Societe Generale Corporate & Investment Banking, Standard Chartered Bank, Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corp, UOB, Export-Import Bank of the Republic of China, and Westpac. Export Development Canada, Industrial & Commercial Bank of China, and Mizuho Bank joined as mandated lead arrangers.
staff_comments: 1. AidData assumes equal contributions by each member of the syndicate. $980 million divided by 17 participants is $57.65 million from each member of the syndicate.
combined_text:
# Sector
BUSINESS AND OTHER SERVICES

# Title
ICBC participates in $980 million syndicated loan for Reliance Industries for debt refinancing purposes

# Description
In March 2016, Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) participated in a $980 million syndicated loan facility agreement with Reliance Industries. The borrowing terms of the loan are unknown. The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower to refinance an existing facility (loan) that it contracted in August 2010. The participating banks in the March 2016 syndicated loan included ANZ, Bank of America, Bank of Nova Scotia Asia, Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ, Barclays Bank, Citibank, Credit Agricole CIB, DBS, Societe Generale Corporate & Investment Banking, Standard Chartered Bank, Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corp, UOB, Export-Import Bank of the Republic of China, and Westpac. Export Development Canada, Industrial & Commercial Bank of China, and Mizuho Bank joined as mandated lead arrangers.
justification: The project involves financial services for debt refinancing without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Syndicated loan facility for debt refinancing purposes, no specific environmental or energy-related components mentioned

title: Bank of China contributes $80 million to a syndicated loan to State Bank of India (Hong Kong) (Linked to Project ID#96813)
description: In June 2016, the Bank of China contributed $80 million in a $500 million syndicated loan to the State Bank of India (Hong Kong), an Indian state-owned bank. The loan had a three-year term (maturity) and the interest rate for this loan was 1.692%  Joint book-runners and mandated lead arrangers included BNP Paribas, Bank of America, Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ, Citi, DBS, HSBC, National Bank of Abu Dhabi, and Wells Fargo Bank. 77 Bank, Bank of Taiwan, Hua Nan Commercial Bank, KGI Bank, Land Bank of Taiwan, Shikoku Bank, and CMB Wing Lung Bank joined the syndicate as mandated lead arrangers. See project ID#96813 for CMB Wing Lung Bank's contribution which was $22 million. The loan proceeds were to be used by the borrower for general corporate and working capital purposes.  The leads collectively retained 60% of the deal on their books, with Bank of America Merrill Lynch keeping $50m, Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ $40m, and Wells Fargo $37.875m. BNP Paribas, Citi, DBS, HSBC, and National Bank of Abu Dhabi took $35.025m each. Among incoming lenders, the Bank of China received the maximum amount of $80m, while the Bank of Taiwan took $30m, Wing Lung Bank $22m, and Hua Nan Commercial Bank and KGI Bank $20m each. Land Bank of Taiwan and 77 Bank were allotted $10m apiece and Chugoku Bank received $5m.
staff_comments: 1. As of March 2017, the Government of India held around 61.23% equity shares in the State Bank of India. The Life Insurance Corporation of India, itself state-owned, is the largest non-promoter shareholder in the company with 8.82% shareholding.2. This loan carried a 1.692% interest rate (AidData calculated the interest rate as follows: 0.842% [6-month LIBOR in June 2009] + 0.85% [85 basis points] = 1.692%).
combined_text:
# Sector
BUSINESS AND OTHER SERVICES

# Title

# Description

See project ID#96813 for CMB Wing Lung Bank's contribution which was $22 million. The loan proceeds were to be used by the borrower for general corporate and working capital purposes.  The leads collectively retained 60% of the deal on their books, with Bank of America Merrill Lynch keeping $50m, Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ $40m, and Wells Fargo $37.875m.
